awd_titl_txt: Automorphic Forms on Reductive Groups and Their Covers
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project studies functions arising in number theory that exhibit special symmetry properties under transformations, called automorphic forms. Some of these functions have coefficients that encode important information in arithmetic, and some have recently been connected to aspects of string theory in physics.  The fundamental Langlands Functoriality Conjectures predict subtle relations between different spaces of automorphic forms, a structure that is closely related to many questions in number theory and analysis.  This research project focuses on establishing properties of automorphic forms and new connections between different spaces of automorphic forms.  The project will also support a graduate student and allow the PI and his students to disseminate the work through conferences and seminars.

This project treats automorphic forms and representations on reductive groups and on their metaplectic covers of arbitrary degree. Automorphic forms on reductive groups are the key ingredients of the Langlands Program, and automorphic forms on covers are closely tied to reciprocity laws and related to the congruence subgroup problem. The research focuses on correspondences and on L-functions. In one series of projects, the principal investigator will develop and study new theta correspondences that generalize the classical theta correspondence but involve the tensor product of two small representations.  A second project seeks to give a new Shimura correspondence that is detected by a period involving a theta function on an orthogonal group. This will be established by means of a new relative trace formula. A third set of projects concerns the systematic development of integral representations for L-functions which make use of the residual spectrum. These projects will advance our knowledge of automorphic forms, both on reductive groups and on finite degree covers, our understanding of small automorphic representations, and our understanding of the relations between automorphic forms on different groups.  It will advance our knowledge of number theory and of representation theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Grant 2100206 is a three-year grant to support research in automorphic forms and the training of doctoral students by the PI, Solomon Friedberg. Automorphic forms are functions on groups which are invariant under discrete subgroups.  They play an important role in number theory and representation theory, and also appear in string theory.

 

The Langlands Functorality Conjectures are key conjectures in the theory of automorphic forms.  Roughly, they predict relations between automorphic forms on different groups, relations that are deep and carry arithmetic content. During the period of support, the Principal Investigator and his collaborators Cai and Kaplan completed their proof of a case of these conjectures, giving a new proof of split endoscopic functorial liftings and the first proof for general spin groups.  An earlier manuscript posted on the arxiv was split into pieces with each piece then expanded considerably from its initial form. Two papers have been published: their 101 page paper in Geometric and Functional Analysis in 2022 and their paper (joint with Gourevitch) in Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society in 2023. The last step in their proof, "Doubling constructions: global functoriality for non-generic cuspidal representations," will be published in the November 2024 issue of the Annals of Mathematics (Volume 200, no. 3). Their proof uses the converse theorem and is based on earlier joint work with Ginzburg. (An alternative approach is via the trace formula.)

 

Another method to construct correspondences between automorphic forms is via an integral kernel, and the prototype is the theta correspondence.  The PI and Ginzburg have defined and investigated a theta correspondence for higher covering groups.  To do so, they introduced and studied a theta kernel that involves the tensor product of two representations, one minimal and one small but not minimal. This is a new kind of theta kernel.  They then studied when this lift would be Whittaker, showed that the "Whittaker range" expands for covering groups and that the existence of Whittaker coefficients is related to new kinds of period integrals. This work appeared in their 2024 paper in the Journal of Number Theory.

 

The most famous theta lifting is the Shimura correspondence, which lifts half-integral weight modular forms to modular forms. This correspondence involves the double cover of two-by-two special linear group. Though this map has been studied for over half a century, it is remarkably difficult to understand what happens for higher degree covers.  In joint work with Offen, the PI has established a new Fundamental Lemma, matching orbital integrals for the unit element in the spherical Hecke algebras up to a specific transfer factor. This is a key step towards establishing a Shimura-type lift for the cubic cover of three-by-three special linear group.  This work involves the analysis of a surprising period involving the theta function of the split even orthogonal group of rank 4.  Their paper, "On the cubic Shimura lift to PGL(3): The fundamental lemma," will appear in the Journal of the European Mathematical Society.  Further research on this topic is underway.

 

The PI has been active in training doctoral students.  One student finished his PhD in December 2021, and he has four PhD students at the moment, including one who is very likely to finish his PhD in Fall 2024. He gave a series of 4 lectures for graduate students at the summer workshop APAW 2022 (University of Oregon).  He has also organized a number of international programs, conferences and other events in this area:  New Connections in Number Theory and Physics, Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Cambridge, England, August 1, 2022 to September 23, 2022 (also co-organizer for the two workshops attached the program); AMS Special Session on Automorphic Forms and Representation Theory, Joint Math Meetings, Boston, January 2023; New Connections Between Physics and Number Theory, Pollica Physics Centre, Italy, June 2023; Arithmetic Quantum Field Theory, Center of Mathematical Sciences and Applications, Harvard, February 5, 2024 to March 29, 2024; Solvable Lattice Models, Number Theory and Combinatorics, Trinity College Dublin, Ireland, June 2024.  In addition, he is working with an NSF postdoctoral fellow.  The PI also contributed to the development of the STEM workforce in other ways; in particular he served as Chair (2021-2022) and now Immediate Past Chair (2023-2024) of the US National Commission on Mathematics Instruction (under the US National Academy of Sciences).
